citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the petting zoo area, there was a goat with a health condition that had not been previously observed. During the
inspection, a black and white, female goat (#1244) was observed with cloudy ocular and nasal discharge on both sides of
its face. The eyes appeared normal, however there was a large accumulation of crusted discharge around both eyes. The
licensee stated that he had not observed the condition of this animal and had not sought veterinary care or treatment.
It's important to closely assess the health of the animals during daily observations to ensure that health conditions are
noted in a timely manner and can be communicated with the attending veterinarian for diagnosis and treatment.
The goat must be evaluated by a veterinary for further diagnosis of its health condition. Daily observations of all animals
must be completed to assess their health and well-being, and should include direct and frequent communication with the
attending veterinarian when problems with animal health are observed.
Correct by: April 22, 2024.

There were several areas of the facility in a state of disrepair.
In the camel enclosure, there were several detached wires protruding from the side of the barn. In the same enclosure,
the back wall of the shelter area has detached from the support posts. This wall separation caused an approximately 10"
gap at the base of the building and exposed several sharp nails at the level of the animals. The stalls in the shelter also
contained broken boards and other wood material on the ground.
In the enclosure housing one zebu, there were multiple piles of wooden boards and metal roofing material on the ground.
In the same area, two sections of the wooden fence were also detached from the posts.
Failure to maintain enclosure shelters and fencing can allow for gaps, unstable structures, or sharp points which can
result in injury, entrapment, or escape of the animals.
Facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them.

There were several enclosures that had large accumulations of feces and used bedding materials. In the pasture that
regularly houses the zebu and Highland bull, there was a large pile of feces and bedding material that was approximately
4 feet high. In the shelter for the camel, there was also a large accumulation of feces in several of the stalls. Lastly, the
small building located above the nature trail, had a large pile of feces and bedding material which was approximately 4
feet high.
Failure to remove accumulations of excreta from primary enclosures can allow for the spread of disease hazards, create
unpleasant odors, and attract pests.
Excreta shall be removed as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals, minimize disease hazards, and
reduce odors.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Catherine Beckwith, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist
Jeffrey Shepherd, Assistant Director n
